INTERGROWTH-21st Body Composition Equations: Improved

Source: vignettes/articles/ig-nbs-body-composition-improved.Rmd
ig-nbs-body-composition-improved.Rmd

Though Villar et al. (2017) published centiles for body composition (fat mass, body fat percentage, and fat-free mass) in newborns from the INTERGROWTH-21st project, they did not publish the parameters of the models used to generate their centiles. To implement these standards in our package we re-derives these values, in this case using the published data to work back to linear equations for the median and SD of each standard.

Extracting models from published data

Custom functions

The following custom functions fit linear models to each INTERGROWTH-21st body composition standard, then print the results:

#' Extract standard deviation from percentiles
#' @param P50 Value of y at mean
#' @param PX Value of y at percentile specified by p
#' @param p Percentile at which y = PX
std_deviation <- function(P50, PX, p) (PX - P50) / qnorm(p = p)

#' Model equation for median (50th centile); print to console
#' @param df A dataframe with columns gest_age and P50. Used to fit LM and
#' get standard deviation.
LM_median <- function(df) {
  model <- lm(P50 ~ gest_age, data = df)
  std_dev <- mapply(FUN = std_deviation,
                     list(df$P50), list(df$P03, df$P10, df$P90, df$P97),
                     list(0.03, 0.10, 0.90, 0.97)) |>
    median(na.rm = TRUE)
  str_model <- paste("y =", coef(model)[[1]], "+",
                     coef(model)[[2]], "* x", "+",
                     "z * ", std_dev)
  str_model
}

Fat mass

Males 

fmfga_male <- gigs::ig_nbs$fmfga$male$percentiles
LM_median(fmfga_male)
## [1] "y = -1134.2 + 5.31428571428571 * x + z *  152.063468718999"
# LM_stddev(fmfga_male)
# t <- LM_stddev2(fmfga_male)

Females 

fmfga_female <- gigs::ig_nbs$fmfga$female$percentiles
LM_median(fmfga_female)
## [1] "y = -840.2 + 4.38571428571429 * x + z *  156.844908065072"

Body fat percentage

Males 

bfpfga_male <- gigs::ig_nbs$bfpfga$male$percentiles
LM_median(bfpfga_male)
## [1] "y = -17.68 + 0.0985714285714286 * x + z *  3.66742948654018"

Females 

bfpfga_female <- gigs::ig_nbs$bfpfga$female$percentiles
LM_median(bfpfga_female)
## [1] "y = -9.02000000000002 + 0.0728571428571429 * x + z *  3.97955114496913"

Fat-free mass

Males 

ffmfga_male <- gigs::ig_nbs$ffmfga$male$percentiles
LM_median(ffmfga_male)
## [1] "y = -2487.6 + 19.9857142857143 * x + z *  276.479034034543"

Females 

ffmfga_female <- gigs::ig_nbs$ffmfga$female$percentiles
LM_median(ffmfga_female)
## [1] "y = -1279 + 15.0428571428572 * x + z *  261.060010982616"

Summary

Fat mass:

Standard Sex Equation
Fat mass Male \(\operatorname{fat\_mass} = -1134.2 + 37.2 (\operatorname{GA}) + z \times 152.063\)
Fat mass Female \(\operatorname{fat\_mass} = -840.2 + 30.7 (\operatorname{GA}) + z \times 156.844\)
Body fat % Male \(\operatorname{body\_fat\_\%} = -17.68 + 0.69 (\operatorname{GA}) + z \times 3.6674\)
Body fat % Female \(\operatorname{body\_fat\_\%} = -9.02 + 0.51 (\operatorname{GA}) + z \times 3.9795\)
Fat-free mass Male \(\operatorname{fat\_free\_mass} = -2487.6 + 139.9 (\operatorname{GA}) + z \times 276.479\)
Fat-free mass Female \(\operatorname{fat\_free\_mass} = -1279 + 105.3 (\operatorname{GA}) + z \times 261.060\)

Comparing fitted values with published values

All plotting code for this section can be found in the source code for this vignette.

Observed vs fitted values

Observed and estimated normative centiles for body composition measures according to gestational age and sex. Centiles (3rd, 10th, 50th, 90th, and 97th) for fat mass (a males; b females); body fat percentage (c males; d females); and fat-free mass (e males; f females) according to gestational age. Red circles show the observed value for that centile and gestational age; dashed lines show estimates from linear equations fitted to these observed values.

Difference between observed and fitted values

Difference between observed and estimated centile values for body composition measures according to gestational age and sex. Circles show differences between observed and estimated values for fat mass (a males; b females); body fat percentage (c males; d females); and fat-free mass (e males; f females) according to gestational age, coloured by centiles (3rd, 10th, 50th, 90th and 97th).

Bland-Altman plots for reference and predicted values

Bland-Altman plots for observed and estimated centile values for body composition measures according to gestational age and sex. Circles show differences between observed and estimated values for fat mass (a males; b females); body fat percentage (c males; d females); and fat-free mass (e males; f females) according to the average of the two measurements.

References

Villar J, Puglia FA, Fenton TR, Ismal LC, Staines-Urias E, Giuliani F, et al. Body composition at birth and its relationship with neonatal anthropometric ratios: the newborn body composition study of the INTERGROWTH-21st project Pediatric Research 2017, 82:305-316. doi: 10.1038/pr.2017.52
